bioghist.p: Sir John Anthony Pople (1925-2004) was a theoretical chemist. Born in Burnham on Sea, Somerset, England, he attended Bristol Grammar School. He received his B. A. (in 1946) and doctorate (in 1951) degrees in mathematics from Cambridge University in the United Kingdom. He moved to the United States of America in the early 1960s, where he lived the rest of his life, though he retained British citizenship. In 1993 he moved from Carnegie Mellon University , where his earlier accomplishments were made, to Northwestern University. He received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1998. He was made a fellow of the Royal Society in 1961, and was knighted in 2003. His first major contribution was a theory of approximate molecular orbital (MO) calculations on pi electron systems in 1953, identical to the one developed by Rudolph Pariser and Robert G. Parr in the same year, and now called the Pariser-Parr-Pople method. Subsequently, he developed the methods of Complete Neglect of Differential Overlap (CNDO) (in 1965) and Intermediate Neglect of Differential Overlap (INDO) for approximate MO calculations on three-dimensional molecules, and other developments in computational chemistry. He pioneered the development of more sophisticated computational methods, so called ab initio methods, that used basis sets of either Slater type orbitals or Gaussian orbitals to model the wave function. He was instrumental in the development of one of the most widely used computational chemistry packages, the "GAUSSIAN" suite of programs.

scopecontent.p: This collection includes papers from Pople's days as a student, from his time at Carnegie Mellon University, and some from his time at Northwestern University. Also included are records of some of his many awards and honors, and drafts and correspondence regarding many of his papers. Papers relating to Pople's early academic career include school reports from grammar school, grades, exams, lecture notes from Cambridge (including notebooks for astronomy, mathematics, physics and chemistry), a copy of his dissertation, and correspondence about job offers. His Carnegie Mellon records (1964-1996) consist largely of files regarding students, post-doctoral fellows, and colleagues. These materials include nomination and recommendation letters, administrative records, such as budgets and travel expenses, comments on articles by students, and correspondence regarding jointly published papers. The materials form Pople's time at Northwestern University include reprints, nomination and recommendation letters, administrative and personnel files and correspondence regarding his receipt of the Nobel Prize. The collection also includes Pople's computational notes (1948-1950s), drafts of his original PPP work (1952-1953), drafts of many of his published papers, along with copies of articles on related topics and correspondence with co-authors and publishers, files on various conferences and meetings in which Pople participated, a packet of information for laureates attending the 1991 Nobel Jubilee, and some of the awards and certificates Pople received throughout his career.
